actions-list.actionItem: The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.J. Res. 130.

Rule provides for consideration of S.J. Res. 80, H.J. Res. 130, H.J. Res. 131, H. Con. Res. 58, H.R. 1949, H.R. 3109, H.R. 5107 and H.R. 5214. The resolution provides for consideration of S.J. Res. 80, H.J. Res. 130, H.J. Res. 131, H. Con. Res. 58, H.R. 1949, H.R. 3109, H.R. 5107, and H.R. 5214 under a closed rule with one hour of general debate on each measure. The resolution also provides for one motion to recommit on H.J. Res. 130, H.J. Res. 131, H.R. 1949, H.R. 3109, H.R. 5107, and H.R. 5214, and one motion to commit S.J. Res. 80.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 879. H.J. Res. 130 — "Providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Bureau of Land Management relating to "Buffalo Field Office Record of Decision and Approved Resource Management Plan Amendment"."

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 888, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the resolution and by voice vote, announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Raskin demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 888.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to refer Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 213

actions-list.actionItem: The previous question on the motion to refer was ordered without objection.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on the Clark (MA) motion to refer H. Res. 888.
Ms. Clark (MA) moved to refer to Ethics.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 888 — "Censuring and condemning Delegate Stacey Plaskett and removing her from the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence for conduct that reflects discreditably on the House of Representatives for colluding with convicted felony sex offender Jeffrey Epstein during a congressional hearing."

actions-list.header: QUESTION OF THE PRIVILEGES OF THE HOUSE
actions-list.actionItem: Mr. Norman rose to a question of the privileges of the House and offered the resolution. The Chair directed the Clerk to report the resolution. Upon examination of the resolution, the Chair determined that the resolution did constitute a question of the privileges of the House.

actions-list.header: NOTIFICATION OF INTENT TO OFFER RESOLUTION
actions-list.actionItem: Mr. Norman notified the House of his intent to offer a privileged resolution pursuant to clause 2(a)(1) of rule IX. The Chair announced that a determination will be made at the time designated for consideration of the resolution.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 236
actions-list.actionItem: 183, 4 Present (Roll no. 292).
Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 878 — "Disapproving the behavior of Representative Jesús G. "Chuy" García of Illinois."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 217

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 879 — "Providing for consideration of the joint resolution (S.J. Res. 80) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Bureau of Land Management relating to ''National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska Integrated Activity Plan Record of Decision''; providing for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 130) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Bureau of Land Management relating to ''Buffalo Field Office Record of Decision and Approved Resource Management Plan Amendment''; providing for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 131) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Bureau of Land Management relating to ''Coastal Plain Oil and Gas Leasing Program Record of Decision''; providing for consideration of the concurrent resolution (H. Con. Res. 58) denouncing the horrors of socialism; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1949) to repeal restrictions on the export and import of natural gas; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3109) to require the Secretary of Energy to direct the National Petroleum Council to issue a report with respect to petrochemical refineries in the United States, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 5107) to repeal the Comprehensive Policing and Justice Reform Amendment Act of 2022 enacted by the District of Columbia Council; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 5214) to require mandatory pretrial and post conviction detention for crimes of violence and dangerous crimes and require mandatory cash bail for certain offenses that pose a threat to public safety or order in the District of Columbia, and for other purposes; and for other purposes."

The Chair put the question on agreeing to the resolution and by voice vote, announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. McGovern demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.

actions-list.header: On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 217

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 879 — "Providing for consideration of the joint resolution (S.J. Res. 80) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Bureau of Land Management relating to ''National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska Integrated Activity Plan Record of Decision''; providing for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 130) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Bureau of Land Management relating to ''Buffalo Field Office Record of Decision and Approved Resource Management Plan Amendment''; providing for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 131) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Bureau of Land Management relating to ''Coastal Plain Oil and Gas Leasing Program Record of Decision''; providing for consideration of the concurrent resolution (H. Con. Res. 58) denouncing the horrors of socialism; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1949) to repeal restrictions on the export and import of natural gas; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3109) to require the Secretary of Energy to direct the National Petroleum Council to issue a report with respect to petrochemical refineries in the United States, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 5107) to repeal the Comprehensive Policing and Justice Reform Amendment Act of 2022 enacted by the District of Columbia Council; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 5214) to require mandatory pretrial and post conviction detention for crimes of violence and dangerous crimes and require mandatory cash bail for certain offenses that pose a threat to public safety or order in the District of Columbia, and for other purposes; and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by recorded vote (2/3 required): 427
actions-list.actionItem: 1 (Roll no. 289).
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 4405.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Jordan moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 4405 — "To require the Attorney General to release all documents and records in possession of the Department of Justice relating to Jeffrey Epstein, and for other purposes."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 879, the Chair put the question on ordering the previous question, and by voice vote announced that the noes had prevailed. Ms. Foxx demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 879.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 879 — "Providing for consideration of the joint resolution (S.J. Res. 80) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Bureau of Land Management relating to ''National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska Integrated Activity Plan Record of Decision''; providing for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 130) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Bureau of Land Management relating to ''Buffalo Field Office Record of Decision and Approved Resource Management Plan Amendment''; providing for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 131) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Bureau of Land Management relating to ''Coastal Plain Oil and Gas Leasing Program Record of Decision''; providing for consideration of the concurrent resolution (H. Con. Res. 58) denouncing the horrors of socialism; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1949) to repeal restrictions on the export and import of natural gas; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3109) to require the Secretary of Energy to direct the National Petroleum Council to issue a report with respect to petrochemical refineries in the United States, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 5107) to repeal the Comprehensive Policing and Justice Reform Amendment Act of 2022 enacted by the District of Columbia Council; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 5214) to require mandatory pretrial and post conviction detention for crimes of violence and dangerous crimes and require mandatory cash bail for certain offenses that pose a threat to public safety or order in the District of Columbia, and for other purposes; and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to without objection.
Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 887 — "Electing Members to certain standing committees of the House of Representatives."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to without objection.
Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 886 — "Electing a member to a certain standing committee of the House of Representatives."

The House received a communication from the Honorable Nydia M. Velazquez. Ms. Velazquez submitted her resignation from the Committee on Natural Resources effective November 18, 2025. The resignation was accepted without objection.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches, which by direction of the Chair would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Ms. Tlaib to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of November 18.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable David J. Taylor to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
